case_vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who notes that the way in which he plays has changed and that he has been limping, favoring his left leg. When asked, the patient states that his left knee hurts. He is afebrile and vital signs are stable. The patient is well nourished and meeting all developmental milestones. On physical examination, the knee has a full range of motion; however, passive motion elicits pain in the left hip. An X-ray is performed and reveals a flattened left femoral head.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My left knee hurts and I've been walking with a limp, favoring my left leg.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your left knee?
No, I haven't had any injuries or trauma to my knee.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or activity level?
No, my weight and activity level haven't changed recently.
Have you had any recent illnesses or infections?
No, I haven't had any recent illnesses or infections.
Have you had any family history of knee pain or injuries?
There's no mention of a family history of knee pain or injuries in my case.
Final Diagnosis: Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD)
